Checkers

Class GameState

  • java.lang.Object
    • Checkers.GameState

  • public class GameState
extends java.lang.Object
    Represents a game state with a 8x8 checkers board. Cells are numbered as follows: col 0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 row ------------------------- 0 | 0 1 2 3 | 0 1 | 4 5 6 7 | 1 2 | 8 9 10 11 | 2 3 | 12 13 14 15 | 3 4 | 16 17 18 19 | 4 5 | 20 21 22 23 | 5 6 | 24 25 26 27 | 6 7 | 28 29 30 31 | 7 ------------------------- 0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 The starting board looks like this: col 0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 row ------------------------- 0 | rr rr rr rr | 0 1 | rr rr rr rr | 1 2 | rr rr rr rr | 2 3 | .. .. .. .. | 3 4 | .. .. .. .. | 4 5 | ww ww ww ww | 5 6 | ww ww ww ww | 6 7 | ww ww ww ww | 7 ------------------------- 0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 The red player starts from the top of the board (row 0,1,2) The white player starts from the bottom of the board (row 5,6,7), Red moves first. Note that there is one way of representing the cells with one number and one way of representing them with two. You may use either one.

    • Method Detail

      • reversed

        GameState reversed()
        Constructs a state that is the result of rotating the board 180 degrees and swapping colours.

      • get

        int get(int pPos)
        Gets the content of a cell in the board. This function returns a byte representing the contents of the cell, using the enumeration values in ECell For example, to check if cell 23 contains a white piece, you would check if (lBoard.At(23)&CELL_WHITE) to check if it is a red piece, (lBoard.At(23)&CELL_RED) and to check if it is a king, you would check if (lBoard.At(23)&CELL_KING)

      • set

        void set(int pPos,
         int v)
        Sets the content of a cell in the board.

      • get

        int get(int pR,
        int pC)
        Gets the content of a cell in the board, from row and column number. Rows are numbered (0 to 7) from the upper row in the board, as seen by the player this program is playing. Columns are numbered starting from the left (also 0 to 7). Cells corresponding to white squares in the board, which will never contain a piece, always return CELL_INVALID If the cell falls outside of the board, return CELL_INVALID You can use it in the same way as the version that requires a cell index

      • rowColToCell

        static int rowColToCell(int pRow,
                        int pCol)
        Gets the index in the array representation of the board which corresponds to a certain row and column number. It doesn't check if it corresponds to a black square in the board, or if it falls within the board. If it doesn't, the result is undefined, and the program is likely to crash
        Parameters:
        pRow -
        pCol -
        Returns:
        the cell corresponding to a row and col

      • tryMove

        void tryMove(java.util.Vector<Checkers.Move> pMoves,
             int pCell,
             boolean pKing)
        Tries to make a move from a certain position, and inserts valid move choices into a vector.
        Parameters:
        pMoves - vector where the valid moves will be inserted
        pCell - the cell where the move is tried from
        pOther - the ECell code corresponding to the player who is not making the move
        pKing - true if the piece is a king

      • findPossibleMoves

        void findPossibleMoves(java.util.Vector<GameState> pStates)
        Finds possible moves and stores these in a vector in the current game state.
        Parameters:
        pStates - the current game state

      • doMove

        public void doMove(Checkers.Move pMove)
        Transforms the board by performing a move. Note: This doesn't check that the move is valid, so you should only use it with moves returned by FindPossibleMoves.
        Parameters:
        pMove - the move to perform

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString(int pPlayer)
        Converts the board to a human-readable string for printing purposes. Note: Use for debug purposes and print to System.err. Don't call it in the final version.

      • toMessage

        public java.lang.String toMessage()
        Converts the board to a machine-readable string ready to be printed to System.out. Note: This is used for passing board states between clients.

      • getMove

        public final Checkers.Move getMove()
        Gets the last move made (the move that led to the current state).
